content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

From the thumbnail view, I see a single piece of tissue, which is predominantly composed of adipose (fatty) tissue. Embedded within this fatty tissue, there is one distinct, well-circumscribed, basophilic (dark purple) nodule that is highly suspicious for a lymph node. The rest of the tissue appears fragmented and less cellular.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, the primary task for this specimen type is to identify all lymph nodes and assess them for metastatic cancer. The area highlighted by the green box is the most obvious and likely the only lymph node candidate on this slide. Its dense cellularity and distinct border make it stand out from the surrounding fat, making it the first and most important area to examine at high magnification. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, I confirm the structure is a lymph node. It is composed of a dense population of lymphocytes. The overall architecture appears reactive, with some preserved follicular structures. I do not see any atypical glandular formations or clusters of malignant epithelial cells to suggest metastasis. The dark, thick band running across the node is an artifact, likely a fold in the tissue section or possibly ink. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis.
